thread.title: Rookie Ryan Weber pitches well but Braves lose
thread.title_full: Rookie Ryan Weber pitches well but Braves lose | www.ajc.com

author: Staff
title: Rookie Ryan Weber pitches well but Braves lose
text:
The Nationals' Stephen Strasburg limited the Braves to six hits and one walk Thursday night in six scoreless innings of a 3-0 win that thwarted the Braves’ shot at a three-game sweep and spoiled a third consecutive night of exceptional pitching from a Braves rookie starter.
This time it was Ryan Weber, who allowed five hits and no walks with a career-high 10 strikeouts in seven innings. In his fifth big-league start, he was outstanding. Unfortunately for Weber and the Braves, one of the hits against him was Clint Robinson’s home run on a full-count pitch in the second inning for a 1-0 lead.
Click here to read more from the AJC's David O'Brien on MyAJC.com
Photos: Braves promote Coppolella to GM Mark Bradley on Coppolella promotion
One of the principal architects — unless I miss my guess, the chief architect — of the worst Braves season in a quarter-century was promoted Thursday. Assistant general manager John Coppolella shed the first word of his title and was handed a contract that runs through 2019. Maybe you think that’s a case of failure being rewarded. Here’s where I say you’re wrong. Click here to read more)
Whatever happened to ... Javy Lopez
Photos: Former Braves standout Javy Lopez When Javier “Javy” Lopez was growing up in Puerto Rico, he would practice baseball by hitting rocks off the metal roof of his house in Ponce. The loud noise, which used to drive his parents crazy, would eventually lead to Lopez putting his name in the major league record books for most home runs in a season by a catcher, when he hit 43 in his final season with the Braves in 2003. (Click here to read more)
